content: Cut sweet meals from your regular routine. Go over your regular meal routine. Be on the lookout for sweet foods you tend to consume. If you regularly have meals based around sweet goods, look at ways you can avoid those meals. Think about what you eat on a regular basis. Maybe a lot of your dishes and side dishes tend to be sweet in nature. Do you, say, eat pancakes or a muffin for breakfast a lot? Do you tend to eat things like candied sweet potatoes or sweetened baked beans during dinner? It can be hard to quit cold turkey. You can start by cutting out one sweet meal a week. For example, on Monday mornings, have unsweetened yogurt and fruit for breakfast instead of a muffin. As the weeks go on, you can increase the number of meals you cut. Alter small sources of sweets in your diet. In addition to sweetened meals, you may consume small amounts of sweets throughout the day. Work on being conscious of the sweets you're consuming, and try to find ways to alter or avoid tiny sources of sweet food. [1] Think about tiny sources of sugar you consume. Do you put sugar in your morning coffee? Do you reward yourself with a cookie after a long day at work? Do you tend to mindlessly snack on sugary cereals when bored? Look for healthier alternatives. Try drinking coffee black, or adding low sugar sweeteners. Reward yourself with something that's not related to food, like watching an episode of a TV show you like. Replace sugary snacks with healthy snacks, like nuts and dried fruit. Limit sweets in your home. If you keep a lot of sweet food on hand, you're more likely to consume sweets throughout the day. Avoid purchasing food you know you'll snack on excessively. [2] [3] Don't bring sugary snacks into your home. If you do have a few sugary snacks on hand, try to go for something like a 100-calorie pack of cookies instead of a whole box. Keep sugary foods out of reach. If you have to get on a stepping stool to access a box of cookies, you may be less likely to snack on them. Manage your eating at celebrations and parties. Social gatherings may be a major source of unhealthy eating. Work on ways to avoid overdoing it when attending parties or going out with friends. You'll be less likely to overeat if you feel full before going out. Eat a healthy meal to fill up prior to a social engagement. Bring something healthy to snack on at the party. You could, for example, show up with a fruit or veggie platter. If you're really craving sugar, have a small piece of something. You could take a single cookie or piece of candy. You could have half a slice of cake instead of a whole slice. Cut back on soda and alcoholic beverages. Soda can be a major source of sweets in the diet, and alcoholic drinks often include soda as a mixer. If you tend to drink a lot of soda, find ways to cut back. Instead of sugary soda, opt for diet varieties. You can also try going for something like flavored seltzer water to satisfy your craving for something sweet and carbonated. [4] To replace soda in mixed drinks, try opting for a drink mixed with plain seltzer or order a glass of dry red or white wine instead. Recognize that sugar is addictive. Sugar is addictive and your desire to eat sweets is a result of your brain’s wiring. It is not a character defect or a sign that you are weak. [5] Try to remind yourself of this when you have a craving. Do not beat yourself up for having a sugar craving. The next time you have a craving, try telling yourself something like, “I am craving sugar because of my brain’s wiring. I am not a weak person for craving sugar." Keep your blood sugar levels stable. Ensuring that your blood sugar levels are stable is a good way to prevent sugar cravings. You can do this by ensuring that you eat regular meals and snacks throughout the day. It is also important to eat foods that your body will metabolize slowly, such as complex carbohydrates and proteins. [6] Try having a meal or snack once every three hours to help keep your blood sugar levels stable. Focus on eating foods that will help to stabilize your blood sugar, such as fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. [7] Indulge cravings with fruit. If you need something sweet , eat some fruits like peaches, apples or bananas. You can also tried frozen fruits or dried fruits. This is a healthy way to satisfy cravings without adding a lot of excess sugar to your diet. [8] You can also add fruit to foods you would normally sweeten with sugar. For example, top oatmeal and cereal with fruit. Add extracts over sugar in recipes. Something like vanilla extract, citrus extract, or almond extract can be added to a recipe in place of sugar. This can sweeten a dish, satisfying your sweet tooth, without adding an onslaught of added table sugar. [9] You can also enhance food with spices over sugar. Try nutmeg, cinnamon, ginger, or allspice instead of sugar. Try artificial sweeteners. Artificial sweeteners do not contain added sugar. You can use them in baked goods, or add them to food and drinks you would normally sweeten with sugar. [10] Artificial sweeteners can be purchased at a local grocery store. They include things like stevia and xylitol. While more research is needed, some studies do indicate there may be a correlation between artificial sweeteners and weight gain. You may want to stick to artificially sweetened products as an occasional treat rather than making them a staple of your diet. [11] Avoid snacking when bored. Many people head for the fridge when they are bored. You may mindlessly snack on sweets during dull moments in your day. Instead of loading up on empty calories when bored, find other ways to entertain yourself. [12] If you're feeling bored, try learning something new. You could read a book or take up a new hobby. You could also do something physical. Try going for a walk or run or playing sports with a friend. Treat yourself on occasion. Cutting out sweets entirely can be difficult for a variety of reasons. At social get togethers, there will frequently be baked goods. It's also difficult to entirely eliminate sweets, especially if they're something you enjoy. Instead of abandoning sweets completely, try treating yourself on special occasions. [13] Many people find they benefit from incorporating a weekly "cheat day" in which they allow themselves to indulge in an otherwise forbidden item. You could, for example, have a donut with your coffee every Sunday morning. Read food labels. It's vital to read food labels when you shop. Many foods that seem healthy are actually loaded with extra sugar. Cutting back on baked goods and sweets may not limit your sugar intake as much as you would think. [14] You may be surprised at the amount of added sugar in unexpected products. There may be sugar in things like bread and pasta sauce. Before purchasing an item, always read the label. A healthy adult should not eat more than 30 grams, or 7 teaspoons of sugar, each day. [15] Recognize the various names of sugar. Sugar is not always referred to as sugar on the ingredients list. Sugar is often obscured as companies will list it as something else. Scan the ingredients list and be on the lookout for the following sugar aliases: [16] Words that end in "-ose" are often just sugar. Be on the lookout for words like glucose, sucrose, and maltose. A product may also contain ingredients that contain a high amount of sugar. Avoid buying products that contain honey, maple syrup, molasses, hydrolyzed starch, corn syrup, coconut palm sugar, and agave nectar. Look for alternatives to sweets. If you have a sweet tooth, buy alternatives to sweets at your local grocery store. Be on the lookout for products that can satisfy your cravings without adding a lot of extra sugar to your diet. [17] Milk tends to contain a lot of sugar. If you enjoy milk, try skim milk over regular varieties. This contains less sugar. Watch out for high sugar beverages. Juice tends to contain a lot of added sugar. Look for juice without added sugar or opt for an orange over a glass of orange juice in the morning. Make healthier baked goods at home. Stop buying sugary baked goods at the grocery store. You can actually cut back on the amount of sugar in a baked good recipe without noticing too much. For example, try add about one-half or one-third of the regular amount of sugar. This will lessen the amount of sugar you consume without affecting your baked goods too much. [18] [19]

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time">How to Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Changing_Your_Eating_Habits_sub" id="">Changing Your Eating Habits</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Managing_Cravings_sub" id="">Managing Cravings</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Making_Wise_Shopping_Decisions_sub" id="">Making Wise Shopping Decisions</a>

<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=paulchernyak%2Clpc#paulchernyak%2Clpc">Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>. Paul Chernyak is a Licensed Professional Counselor in Chicago. He graduated from the American School of Professional Psychology in 2011.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">19 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Sweets can be a tasty treat to reward yourself after a long day. However, many people have trouble consuming sweets in moderation. If you find yourself going overboard on sugary snacks, there are many things you can do to curb your cravings. Try changing your eating habits by removing sugary meals and snacks from your diet. Work on indulging cravings with healthy alternatives, like fruit. When you shop, be on the lookout for sugar. Foods you would not expect, like pasta sauces and breads, are often loaded with added sugars.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Changing_Your_Eating_Habits_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Changing_Your_Eating_Habits">Changing Your Eating Habits</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d8/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_01317236b8" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_01317236b8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d8/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Cut sweet meals from your regular routine.</b> Go over your regular meal routine. Be on the lookout for sweet foods you tend to consume. If you regularly have meals based around sweet goods, look at ways you can avoid those meals.

<ul>
<li>Think about what you eat on a regular basis. Maybe a lot of your dishes and side dishes tend to be sweet in nature. Do you, say, eat pancakes or a muffin for breakfast a lot? Do you tend to eat things like candied sweet potatoes or sweetened baked beans during dinner?</li>
<li>It can be hard to quit cold turkey. You can start by cutting out one sweet meal a week. For example, on Monday mornings, have unsweetened yogurt and fruit for breakfast instead of a muffin. As the weeks go on, you can increase the number of meals you cut.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-2.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_863a347251" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_863a347251')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-2.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Alter small sources of sweets in your diet.</b> In addition to sweetened meals, you may consume small amounts of sweets throughout the day. Work on being conscious of the sweets you're consuming, and try to find ways to alter or avoid tiny sources of sweet food.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Think about tiny sources of sugar you consume. Do you put sugar in your morning coffee? Do you reward yourself with a cookie after a long day at work? Do you tend to mindlessly snack on sugary cereals when bored?</li>
<li>Look for healthier alternatives. Try drinking coffee black, or adding low sugar sweeteners. Reward yourself with something that's not related to food, like watching an episode of a TV show you like. Replace sugary snacks with healthy snacks, like nuts and dried fruit.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_7357ac2db0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7357ac2db0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Limit sweets in your home.</b> If you keep a lot of sweet food on hand, you're more likely to consume sweets throughout the day. Avoid purchasing food you know you'll snack on excessively.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Don't bring sugary snacks into your home. If you do have a few sugary snacks on hand, try to go for something like a 100-calorie pack of cookies instead of a whole box.</li>
<li>Keep sugary foods out of reach. If you have to get on a stepping stool to access a box of cookies, you may be less likely to snack on them.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-4.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_7f8c015170" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7f8c015170')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-4.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Manage your eating at celebrations and parties.</b> Social gatherings may be a major source of unhealthy eating. Work on ways to avoid overdoing it when attending parties or going out with friends.

<ul>
<li>You'll be less likely to overeat if you feel full before going out. Eat a healthy meal to fill up prior to a social engagement.</li>
<li>Bring something healthy to snack on at the party. You could, for example, show up with a fruit or veggie platter.</li>
<li>If you're really craving sugar, have a small piece of something. You could take a single cookie or piece of candy. You could have half a slice of cake instead of a whole slice.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-5.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_d3787f4354" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d3787f4354')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-5.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Cut back on soda and alcoholic beverages.</b> Soda can be a major source of sweets in the diet, and alcoholic drinks often include soda as a mixer. If you tend to drink a lot of soda, find ways to cut back. Instead of sugary soda, opt for diet varieties. You can also try going for something like flavored seltzer water to satisfy your craving for something sweet and carbonated.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>To replace soda in mixed drinks, try opting for a drink mixed with plain seltzer or order a glass of dry red or white wine instead.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Managing_Cravings_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Managing_Cravings">Managing Cravings</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Recognize that sugar is addictive.</b> Sugar is addictive and your desire to eat sweets is a result of your brain’s wiring. It is not a character defect or a sign that you are weak.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Try to remind yourself of this when you have a craving. Do not beat yourself up for having a sugar craving.
<ul>
<li>The next time you have a craving, try telling yourself something like, “I am craving sugar because of my brain’s wiring. I am not a weak person for craving sugar."</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Keep your blood sugar levels stable.</b> Ensuring that your blood sugar levels are stable is a good way to prevent sugar cravings. You can do this by ensuring that you eat regular meals and snacks throughout the day. It is also important to eat foods that your body will metabolize slowly, such as complex carbohydrates and proteins.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Try having a meal or snack once every three hours to help keep your blood sugar levels stable. Focus on eating foods that will help to stabilize your blood sugar, such as fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-6.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_29e40decbf" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_29e40decbf')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-6.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Indulge cravings with fruit.</b> If you need something <i>sweet</i>, eat some fruits like peaches, apples or bananas. You can also tried frozen fruits or dried fruits. This is a healthy way to satisfy cravings without adding a lot of excess sugar to your diet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You can also add fruit to foods you would normally sweeten with sugar. For example, top oatmeal and cereal with fruit.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-7.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_34bdc4c78a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_34bdc4c78a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-7.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add extracts over sugar in recipes.</b> Something like vanilla extract, citrus extract, or almond extract can be added to a recipe in place of sugar. This can sweeten a dish, satisfying your sweet tooth, without adding an onslaught of added table sugar.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You can also enhance food with spices over sugar. Try nutmeg, cinnamon, ginger, or allspice instead of sugar.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-8.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_bd2c70ec8a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bd2c70ec8a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-8.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try artificial sweeteners.</b> Artificial sweeteners do not contain added sugar. You can use them in baked goods, or add them to food and drinks you would normally sweeten with sugar.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Artificial sweeteners can be purchased at a local grocery store. They include things like stevia and xylitol.</li>
<li>While more research is needed, some studies do indicate there may be a correlation between artificial sweeteners and weight gain. You may want to stick to artificially sweetened products as an occasional treat rather than making them a staple of your diet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-9.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_a6250e98b0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a6250e98b0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-9.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid snacking when bored.</b> Many people head for the fridge when they are bored. You may mindlessly snack on sweets during dull moments in your day. Instead of loading up on empty calories when bored, find other ways to entertain yourself.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you're feeling bored, try learning something new. You could read a book or take up a new hobby.</li>
<li>You could also do something physical. Try going for a walk or run or playing sports with a friend.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-10.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_84a2cc27b3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_84a2cc27b3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-10.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Treat yourself on occasion.</b> Cutting out sweets entirely can be difficult for a variety of reasons. At social get togethers, there will frequently be baked goods. It's also difficult to entirely eliminate sweets, especially if they're something you enjoy. Instead of abandoning sweets completely, try treating yourself on special occasions.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Many people find they benefit from incorporating a weekly "cheat day" in which they allow themselves to indulge in an otherwise forbidden item. You could, for example, have a donut with your coffee every Sunday morning.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Making_Wise_Shopping_Decisions_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Wise_Shopping_Decisions">Making Wise Shopping Decisions</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-11.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_1f81cd7cf3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1f81cd7cf3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-11.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Read food labels.</b> It's vital to read food labels when you shop. Many foods that seem healthy are actually loaded with extra sugar. Cutting back on baked goods and sweets may not limit your sugar intake as much as you would think.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You may be surprised at the amount of added sugar in unexpected products. There may be sugar in things like bread and pasta sauce.</li>
<li>Before purchasing an item, always read the label. A healthy adult should not eat more than 30 grams, or 7 teaspoons of sugar, each day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-12.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_b2a9144726" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b2a9144726')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-12.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Recognize the various names of sugar.</b> Sugar is not always referred to as sugar on the ingredients list. Sugar is often obscured as companies will list it as something else. Scan the ingredients list and be on the lookout for the following sugar aliases:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Words that end in "-ose" are often just sugar. Be on the lookout for words like glucose, sucrose, and maltose.</li>
<li>A product may also contain ingredients that contain a high amount of sugar. Avoid buying products that contain honey, maple syrup, molasses, hydrolyzed starch, corn syrup, coconut palm sugar, and agave nectar.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-13.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_5ed7508d4e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5ed7508d4e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-13.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Look for alternatives to sweets.</b> If you have a sweet tooth, buy alternatives to sweets at your local grocery store. Be on the lookout for products that can satisfy your cravings without adding a lot of extra sugar to your diet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Milk tends to contain a lot of sugar. If you enjoy milk, try skim milk over regular varieties. This contains less sugar.</li>
<li>Watch out for high sugar beverages. Juice tends to contain a lot of added sugar. Look for juice without added sugar or opt for an orange over a glass of orange juice in the morning.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1855301" href="#/Image:Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-14.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_24fa75f067" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_24fa75f067')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-14.jpg/aid1855301-v4-728px-Stop-Eating-Sweets-All-of-the-Time-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make healthier baked goods at home.</b> Stop buying sugary baked goods at the grocery store. You can actually cut back on the amount of sugar in a baked good recipe without noticing too much. For example, try add about one-half or one-third of the regular amount of sugar. This will lessen the amount of sugar you consume without affecting your baked goods too much.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="1855301" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="315760" data-caid="316633" data-cqid="315777" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1567729" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="4">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I try to not eat sweets, but I have to buy sweets for my kids. How can I teach myself to not eat them?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Tell your children you are cutting down on sweets. Make sweets a special treat.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>4</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="416992" data-caid="417865" data-cqid="417009" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1012568" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="6">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Why am I still really thin even though I eat a lot of sweets every day?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">It may be your genetics. However, consuming excessive amounts of sugar is detrimental to your health. You may not feel sick now, but the sugar will damage your body and you will see the results eventually. You should try to cut back on eating sweets. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>6</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="234429" data-caid="235302" data-cqid="234446" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1188217" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if there are sweets in my home and I want to eat them? I can't help myself. I need to get over sugar. What should I do then?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Try to focus on something else, such as an activity. Watching television always helps for me.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>5</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="88159" data-caid="89032" data-cqid="88176" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="660273" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="7">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I stop eating candy all the time? I buy gummies like every single day and after I'm done with them I feel sick. Can you please give me some tips on how to stop eating gummies all the time?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If you have trouble not overeating, avoid keeping gummy candy in your home. If you have trouble even resisting the temptation to buy gummy candy, try avoiding the places where you purchase it. For example, say you stop at the gas station to buy a bag of gummies every day. Try taking a different route home to avoid that gas station. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>3</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>7</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="501365" data-caid="502238" data-cqid="501382" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2602629" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="2">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How can I avoid sweets/dessert at school?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Bring your own snacks, such as fruits and salads, and eat them instead of sweets (try to avoid added sugar in snacks, though).</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

		{{/show_editor_tools}}

			{{/qa_desktop}}

					{{^verifierData.imagePath}}<span>{{verifierData.initials}}</span>{{/verifierData.imagePath}}</a>
			{{/verifierId}}

			{{^verifierId}}
				<div class="qa_person_circle" {{#submitterAvatar}}style="background-image:url({{{submitterAvatar}}})"{{/submitterAvatar}}></div>
			{{/verifierId}}

				<div class="qa_answerer_info">
				{{#verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">
						<a href="{{#formatName}}{{verifierData.name}}{{/formatName}}" target="_blank">{{verifierData.name}}</a>
					</div>
					<div class="qa_user_title">{{{verifierData.blurb}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

				{{^verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">{{{submitterDisplayName}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

				</div>
			</div>

		{{#qa_desktop}}

		</ul>
		{{> thumbs_up_down}}

		</div>
	</div>
</li>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Exercise makes you lose weight just that little bit quicker, and can help curb sugar cravings. Get at least 30 minutes of exercise per day.</li>
<li>Be positive. This <i>diet</i> may feel like torture, but if you believe in yourself. You'll get used to this and it will be much easier.</li>
<li>Avoid dried fruit, it is not healthy. Raisins, dates etc. are just sugar bombs because the sugar in them has been concentrated. Eat 1 to 2 small pieces of whole fruit per day instead.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

title: How to Stop Eating Sweets All of the Time
content_html:
Cut sweet meals from your regular routine. Go over your regular meal routine. Be on the lookout for sweet foods you tend to consume. If you regularly have meals based around sweet goods, look at ways you can avoid those meals.
  • Think about what you eat on a regular basis. Maybe a lot of your dishes and side dishes tend to be sweet in nature. Do you, say, eat pancakes or a muffin for breakfast a lot? Do you tend to eat things like candied sweet potatoes or sweetened baked beans during dinner?
  • It can be hard to quit cold turkey. You can start by cutting out one sweet meal a week. For example, on Monday mornings, have unsweetened yogurt and fruit for breakfast instead of a muffin. As the weeks go on, you can increase the number of meals you cut.
Alter small sources of sweets in your diet. In addition to sweetened meals, you may consume small amounts of sweets throughout the day. Work on being conscious of the sweets you're consuming, and try to find ways to alter or avoid tiny sources of sweet food.[1]
  • Think about tiny sources of sugar you consume. Do you put sugar in your morning coffee? Do you reward yourself with a cookie after a long day at work? Do you tend to mindlessly snack on sugary cereals when bored?
  • Look for healthier alternatives. Try drinking coffee black, or adding low sugar sweeteners. Reward yourself with something that's not related to food, like watching an episode of a TV show you like. Replace sugary snacks with healthy snacks, like nuts and dried fruit.
Limit sweets in your home. If you keep a lot of sweet food on hand, you're more likely to consume sweets throughout the day. Avoid purchasing food you know you'll snack on excessively.[2][3]
  • Don't bring sugary snacks into your home. If you do have a few sugary snacks on hand, try to go for something like a 100-calorie pack of cookies instead of a whole box.
  • Keep sugary foods out of reach. If you have to get on a stepping stool to access a box of cookies, you may be less likely to snack on them.
Manage your eating at celebrations and parties. Social gatherings may be a major source of unhealthy eating. Work on ways to avoid overdoing it when attending parties or going out with friends.
  • You'll be less likely to overeat if you feel full before going out. Eat a healthy meal to fill up prior to a social engagement.
  • Bring something healthy to snack on at the party. You could, for example, show up with a fruit or veggie platter.
  • If you're really craving sugar, have a small piece of something. You could take a single cookie or piece of candy. You could have half a slice of cake instead of a whole slice.
Cut back on soda and alcoholic beverages. Soda can be a major source of sweets in the diet, and alcoholic drinks often include soda as a mixer. If you tend to drink a lot of soda, find ways to cut back. Instead of sugary soda, opt for diet varieties. You can also try going for something like flavored seltzer water to satisfy your craving for something sweet and carbonated.[4]
  • To replace soda in mixed drinks, try opting for a drink mixed with plain seltzer or order a glass of dry red or white wine instead.
Recognize that sugar is addictive. Sugar is addictive and your desire to eat sweets is a result of your brain’s wiring. It is not a character defect or a sign that you are weak.[5] Try to remind yourself of this when you have a craving. Do not beat yourself up for having a sugar craving.
  • The next time you have a craving, try telling yourself something like, “I am craving sugar because of my brain’s wiring. I am not a weak person for craving sugar."
Keep your blood sugar levels stable. Ensuring that your blood sugar levels are stable is a good way to prevent sugar cravings. You can do this by ensuring that you eat regular meals and snacks throughout the day. It is also important to eat foods that your body will metabolize slowly, such as complex carbohydrates and proteins.[6]
  • Try having a meal or snack once every three hours to help keep your blood sugar levels stable. Focus on eating foods that will help to stabilize your blood sugar, such as fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.[7]
Indulge cravings with fruit. If you need something sweet, eat some fruits like peaches, apples or bananas. You can also tried frozen fruits or dried fruits. This is a healthy way to satisfy cravings without adding a lot of excess sugar to your diet.[8]
  • You can also add fruit to foods you would normally sweeten with sugar. For example, top oatmeal and cereal with fruit.
Add extracts over sugar in recipes. Something like vanilla extract, citrus extract, or almond extract can be added to a recipe in place of sugar. This can sweeten a dish, satisfying your sweet tooth, without adding an onslaught of added table sugar.[9]
  • You can also enhance food with spices over sugar. Try nutmeg, cinnamon, ginger, or allspice instead of sugar.
Try artificial sweeteners. Artificial sweeteners do not contain added sugar. You can use them in baked goods, or add them to food and drinks you would normally sweeten with sugar.[10]
  • Artificial sweeteners can be purchased at a local grocery store. They include things like stevia and xylitol.
  • While more research is needed, some studies do indicate there may be a correlation between artificial sweeteners and weight gain. You may want to stick to artificially sweetened products as an occasional treat rather than making them a staple of your diet.[11]
Avoid snacking when bored. Many people head for the fridge when they are bored. You may mindlessly snack on sweets during dull moments in your day. Instead of loading up on empty calories when bored, find other ways to entertain yourself.[12]
  • If you're feeling bored, try learning something new. You could read a book or take up a new hobby.
  • You could also do something physical. Try going for a walk or run or playing sports with a friend.
Treat yourself on occasion. Cutting out sweets entirely can be difficult for a variety of reasons. At social get togethers, there will frequently be baked goods. It's also difficult to entirely eliminate sweets, especially if they're something you enjoy. Instead of abandoning sweets completely, try treating yourself on special occasions.[13]
  • Many people find they benefit from incorporating a weekly "cheat day" in which they allow themselves to indulge in an otherwise forbidden item. You could, for example, have a donut with your coffee every Sunday morning.
Read food labels. It's vital to read food labels when you shop. Many foods that seem healthy are actually loaded with extra sugar. Cutting back on baked goods and sweets may not limit your sugar intake as much as you would think.[14]
  • You may be surprised at the amount of added sugar in unexpected products. There may be sugar in things like bread and pasta sauce.
  • Before purchasing an item, always read the label. A healthy adult should not eat more than 30 grams, or 7 teaspoons of sugar, each day.[15]
Recognize the various names of sugar. Sugar is not always referred to as sugar on the ingredients list. Sugar is often obscured as companies will list it as something else. Scan the ingredients list and be on the lookout for the following sugar aliases:[16]
  • Words that end in "-ose" are often just sugar. Be on the lookout for words like glucose, sucrose, and maltose.
  • A product may also contain ingredients that contain a high amount of sugar. Avoid buying products that contain honey, maple syrup, molasses, hydrolyzed starch, corn syrup, coconut palm sugar, and agave nectar.
Look for alternatives to sweets. If you have a sweet tooth, buy alternatives to sweets at your local grocery store. Be on the lookout for products that can satisfy your cravings without adding a lot of extra sugar to your diet.[17]
  • Milk tends to contain a lot of sugar. If you enjoy milk, try skim milk over regular varieties. This contains less sugar.
  • Watch out for high sugar beverages. Juice tends to contain a lot of added sugar. Look for juice without added sugar or opt for an orange over a glass of orange juice in the morning.
Make healthier baked goods at home. Stop buying sugary baked goods at the grocery store. You can actually cut back on the amount of sugar in a baked good recipe without noticing too much. For example, try add about one-half or one-third of the regular amount of sugar. This will lessen the amount of sugar you consume without affecting your baked goods too much.[18][19]
